Carbon Trading Heats up Capitol Hill (EnergyBiz Insider - Apr. 6,2007)



EnergyBiz Insider - Apr. 6,2007 - Carbon emission constraints are creating quite a stir in Washington. Convinced that the country must act, lawmakers on Capitol Hill are seeking direction from members of the European Union on how to establish an emissions trading scheme.

NATIONAL NEWS






Great Plains Energy and Aquila File Acquisition Approval Applications in Missouri and Kansas



KANSAS CITY, Mo.-(Business Wire)-April 4, 2007 - Great Plains Energy Incorporated (NYSE: GXP), its public utility subsidiary Kansas City Power & Light Company (KCP&L) and Aquila, Inc. (NYSE: ILA) today filed applications with the Missouri Public Service Commission and the Kansas Corporation Commission seeking approval of the proposed acquisition by Great Plains Energy of Aquila.


Apr 5, 2007 DiGiTAL50



Westar Energy to Provide Energy Management Services to



TOPEKA, Kan., April 5 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Westar Energy, Inc. WR announced today that it has entered into an agreement with the Arkansas/Missouri Energy Pool to provide energy management services. The ArkMo Pool is a group of five cities located in northeast Arkansas and southeast Missouri. Westar will provide energy scheduling and power marketing services.

Compensation for Duke Energy's Rogers nearly $27.5M in 2006



CHARLOTTE, N.C. - Duke Energy Corp. President and Chief Executive James E. Rogers received compensation the company valued at nearly $27.5 million in 2006, according to a regulatory filing made Wednesday. Rogers, the 59-year-old former chief executive of Cinergy Corp., took over as Duke's top executive after the company acquired the Cincinnati-based utility last April.

Four firms settle natural gas suit: Ratepayers will get $159.5 million total in refunds if accord is approved.

The settlement stems from a class-action lawsuit over allegations that the four companies boosted gas prices by reporting false data to trade publications and engaging in "wash trades." Strong-arm Tactics: TXU's response an unfortunate step backward



It's one of the most despicable things we've heard in some time. Facing a $210 million penalty for allegedly manipulating the power market in Texas, TXU said it would be compelled to shut power plants. TXU may insist that this is simply a statement of financial reality. But, forgive us, this smacks of blackmail. We can read between the lines: Unless you want sky-high energy prices, back off the ...

Duke Energy Corp. President and Chief Executive James E. Rogers received compensation the company valued at nearly $27.5 million in 2006, according to a regulatory filing made Wednesday. TXU Issues Apology On Plant Closing Issue



DALLAS, April 6 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/-- Today, TXU Corp. (NYSE: TXU) issued the following statements from TXU Corp. CEO John Wilder and Michael McCall, CEO of TXU Wholesale. McCall: 'TXU apologizes for creating any perception of threatening to shut down power plants in Texas. TXU is not permitted to unilaterally shut down power plants. Such a step can only be done after a review by ERCOT.

Hot commodity: PG&amp;E solar cash



The rush is on to get rebates on solar installations, with Pacific Gas & Electric Co. receiving applications for nearly half the cash available under a 10-year state program within its first four months. Passed in January, the California Solar Initiative provides $2.8 billion in rebates with the goal of creating a self-supporting solar industry in California by 2017.

Prospective Buyers of TXU Say Utility Should Try to Settle With Regulators



David Koenig DALLAS (AP) - The private investors trying to buy TXU Corp. said Friday they strongly disagreed with the utility's threat to shut down some of its power plants if it can't settle accusations of price manipulation. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. and Texas Pacific Group said they have no intention of closing plants if they succeed in buying TXU, the largest power generator in Texas. ...


Apr 6, 2007 Canadian Business Magazine



Fire in transformer yard closes nuclear power plant in New York



Caused by electrical fault and fire in a transformer yard the automatic shutdown closed the Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant. The fire, which was quickly extinguished, was outside the nuclear area of the plant and there was no release of radiation, said Diane Screnci of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. 'The plant is stable and reacted normally,' she said.

The Australian government is working on a long-term development plan for the geothermal industry.
